div.p: 1. III:45. Tuesday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— I sent a copy of my Eulogy on La Fayette; and one upon Madison to Mr Thomas L. Winthrop— Began this morning to clear out stones from the eighth seminary plat opened in 1836. but after taking out a bushel basket full, was called away, and left the work unfinished. French took up a dead English-Oak, at the Eastern end of the Seminary, and cleared out another plat; removing the stones and filling up with a mixture of the pond mud, and of garden mould— Morning visit from Mr Joseph Richardson and Mr Jotham Lincoln of Hingham. They spoke of a celebration this day at Scituate of the anniversary of the emancipation of the Slaves, in the British West-India Islands in 1834— Mrs Baxter and her daughter paid an afternoon visit to the Ladies. I answered a Letter from Mr William Thompson of Ohio City— Charles brought with him from Boston a volume of Lectures on Slavery, by the Revd. Benjamin Goodwin D.D. presented to me by William S. Andrews, an Abolitionist.— I received also a Letter from John Hardwick President of the Quincy Lyceum, requesting me to deliver a Lecture before them.
2. IV. Wednesday.

Finished the clearing out of the 8th. plat of the seminary row, and filled with a mixture of orchard pond mud and garden-mould, the vacuities left by the removal of the stones— There is on it a transplanted central peach tree, nearly winter-killed, but reviving, and around it three puny apple-trees, all plucked up in getting out the Stones, and replanted, to perish— French enlarged the circle of broken up ground, about two of the transplanted trees in the next row— Our rasberries cease this day; and we have the first stewed Jenneton pears, not yet quite ripe. I had received some weeks since from the Revd. C. W. Upham of Salem, an invitation to deliver the introductory Lecture to the annual course of the Salem Lyceum, and had postponed too long the return of an answer to his Letter. Yesterday I received from the Revd. Jonathan F. Worcester corresponding Secretary of the Lyceum a repetition of the invitation; with a notice that the Vice-President and Secretary would call on me this day for my answer: they accordingly came this afternoon, and I apologized to them first for not having before this, answered Mr Upham’s Letter; and secondly for declining to deliver this year the Lyceum Lecture, which owing to my engagements, and to the necessity of my attendance at the Meeting of Congress on the 4th. of next month will be impossible— I told them that if my health and circumstances should permit, I would cheerfully deliver the introductory Lecture of the next Season, and that I lamented my inability to comply with their request this Season— Mr Tillson Burrows, a petitioner before Congress for a Pension as an invalid of the last War, was here with Mr Sprout an Attorney, belonging to Wareham, to make a more effective statement of his
case— The Committee on Invalid Pensions have twice reported against his claim, on the score of deficient evidence— There was no positive and adequate testimony to his disability; the commanding Officer under whom he served, and the Surgeon who attended him, being both deceased; another witness insane, and a fourth now absent at sea, and not likely to return home within a year— I explained the character of the evidence indispensable to the success of the claim, intelligibly to Mr Sprout: but Burrows could not understand how he should forfeit his right to a Pension, merely for want of Evidence— I told him I would call up his petition and have it again referred to a Committee; and exhorted him to obtain, and forward further evidence in support of it, if possible— The young Ladies took tea and spent the Evening at Mr Edward Miller’s— Charles and I went to accompany them home— We rode back with them— We had a little Piano music and songs from Mrs Nicholson— Mrs T. B. Adams and Mrs Foster with their families constituted the company— The day was intensely warm, and at Noon I took a bath and swim at Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf.
3. V. Thursday
Hingham— Cohassett— Fishing party. Hingham— home.

At six this morning I went with Charles in his Chaise to Hingham. Mr Beale, with his daughter Caroline, was just before us— But they returned immediately to Quincy. We met at the tavern a Committee of 3. from the inhabitants of the town—Mr Solomon Lincoln, Mr Ford and Mrwho together with Mr Loring, accompanied me to the harbour—where the inhabitants have petitioned Congress for an improvement. I went with Mr Loring in his chaise; and Quincy Thaxter junr went with Charles— We alighted to view the harbour, and the channel which the inhabitants of the Town petition to have deepened— We then went to the house of an old woman, 82 years of age, and blind, named Nicholls, widow of a sometime commander of the revenue Cutter— We went out in boats on a fishing party, and caught a few perch, and Pollocks; and flounders, and Rock-cod; but without much luck, and were called back about noon to a luncheon and after an interval of two hours, we had a dinner of chowder and fried fish— The party consisted of about twenty Gentlemen, among whom were Messrs Richardson, Brooks, and Stearns, clergymen, Solomon and Jotham Lincoln, Ford, Quincy Thaxter, Smith of the Academy, and ten or twelve others, strangers, whose names I do not recollect.— Just after dinner there came up a very heavy thunder gust; after which we returned to Hingham, and attended a tea-party at Mr Loring’s— There were from twenty to thirty Ladies there most of whom were unknown to me, among them Mrs Edward Thaxter and Misses Eliza and Anna Thaxter, Mrs Smith, wife of the preceptor of the Academy—and very handsome— At the dusk of Evening, with my Son, I left the company and returned home— It was near 9 in the Evening when we reached it;—the sky having cleared away cold, with the moon at its third day, and a bright northern light as she went down— This phenomenon has become very frequent in its appearance— Mrs John and Mrs Charles Adams had been spending the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and got home after us. I had been exceedingly cautious to avoid all inflammatories, but came home much exhausted with fatigue. There can be few more sporting days for me
4. V:30. Friday

Deacon Spear was here this morning, and I gave him the Assignment of my pew N. 75 in the Stone Meeting-house to Job Faxon, for which he is to give me his note payable the 1st. of next February, without interest; and he is to take possession, at the payment of the Note— Charles and his wife went to Boston and dined there. Mary and Elizabeth C. Adams took an early dinner, and went in the Carriage, at 2. O’Clock— Charles returned alone about 5. O’Clock, and Mary, Charles’s wife and Elizabeth in the Evening shortly before the bell for nine— I cleared from weeds a plat in the seminary, between the two old plum trees, and enlarged its borders— There are upon it 12 Apple, and 2 Pear seedlings of last year’s growth— Small, and choaked with weeds— French is digging round the seminary transplanted fruit trees of the last three years; none of which are dead, and none of which flourish— Josiah Adams junr. gave me a cane composed of 25 different kinds of wood strung upon a staff of Oak; and glued at the joints, all of the natural colour of each kind of the wood, with one ringlet of ivory, and two of the kinds of wood twice used— I lost the day for writing, by getting engaged in the perusal of the copies of my mother’s Letters—written during the revolutionary War, which absorbed my attention and affected my feelings beyond expression. This is no waste of time—yet it diverted me from that which was my proper occupation.
5. IV:30. Saturday

Cleared from weeds a Seminary plat. West of the two old Plum trees, and enlarged its border There are on it 5 Apple and 2 Pear seedlings of 1835. looking very puny. In the centre of the Plat cleared yesterday, is a Philadelphia Maple 16 inches high. Mr John Thomas of Kingston called this morning and made enquiries concerning his right to bounty Lands as a son of General Thomas of the Revolutionary army, upon whom the command devolved, at the death of Montgomery before Quebec, and who died himself in 1776. upon examination of the Act of Congress of 4. July 1836. he was satisfied that he could have no claim under that: but he supposed he might obtain something by petition. He said his mother was dead, and that he, and one brother named Nathaniel, were joint heirs to his fathers estate— I advised him to make in writing a statement of the facts of his father’s service in the revolutionary war and of his decease; and with proper authenticating documents to transmit them to me; and I promised to ascertain at the general Land-Office whether a Land warrant could issue upon them; and if not I would inform him; so that he and his brother might if the saw fit petition Congress— As the day was cool and the weather fine I walked to Mr Harvey Field’s; and settled the account with him for the wood which he agreed to purchase standing on the Atherton, and Verchild pastures last year. I went with him and viewed the five Acres which he had agreed to clear out, and remove the stones, to the amount of 100 dollars; but as he found more stones than he had expected, instead of carting away the Stones, he has built a strong stone wall across the lot, and divided off the five acres from the rest; and he has not taken up one fourth part of the large stones— He said he had expended much more than the hundred dollars, and hoped I would make some allowance for the stone wall— This I declined, the wall having been made without authority or agreement; and being to me an incumbrance instead of a benefit— He has also left several of the split rocks on the ground, thinking they would be good for cellar stone— He paid me the balance due upon the agreement to clear off the wood 195:39— He having taken upon the 1st. of June my note to Samuel Copeland for woodland—164:55.
I deposited his check at the Quincy Stone Bank, and its amount was credited on my bank account book— A man calling himself Niles Allen, came this afternoon, and said he was one of the passengers in the Steam-boat Ben Sherrod, which some weeks since perished by taking fire on the Mississippi— Many of her passengers lost their lives in that calamity, and Mr Allen said he had very narrowly escaped; and had lost all the property that he had on board— He had agents at New-Orleans who instead of remitting money to him had advised him to draw upon them—and shewed me two Letters to him signed Burke and Watt, shewing sums of several kinds of property in their hands and they advise him in case of wanting money to apply to me—informing him where I reside— He said he had come on here in pursuit of heath, and had fallen short of money—he wished to borrow but I had no money to lend, and was obliged to decline— He finally said he would make out to get along on his journey, with no more than fifty dollars but I could not accommodate him even with so much. I had strong suspicions that he was an imposter— Mrs Lunt was here to visit the Ladies this afternoon; and Midshipman John Q. Adams, his Sister Elizabeth, Hannah Miller and Fanny Foster in the Evening.
6. IV: Sunday.

Communion day— Mr Peter Whitney preached the morning Sermon, from 1. Corinthians 1.23. [“]But we preach Christ crucified, unto the Jews a stumbling block, and unto the Greeks foolishness; 24. But unto them which are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God, and the wisdom of God”— The communion was administered partly by Mr Whitney, and partly by Mr Lunt— Returning home with Louisa C. Smith after the service, met Mr Degrand, who had come out in a Carriage from Boston.— He dined and spent the remainder of the day with me— In the afternoon Mr Lunt preached from James 4.14. “Whereas ye know not what shall be on the morrow”— The Doctrine of the Discourse, was the wisdom, and goodness of God, in denying to mankind the knowledge of the future— Its most impressive passage to my mind was an Allegory of two brothers departing from home together upon a long Journey, terminated by a distant and unexplored ocean to be traversed before reaching the end of their Journey. One of the brothers takes Knowledge for the companion of his way, and the other selects for his fellow-travellers Faith and Hope— On reaching the borders of the dark and dreary Ocean, Knowledge is obliged to take leave of his companion, who embarks alone uncertain of his Fate, and sinking into despair— But there it is that Faith and Hope, prove to the other brother, friends of inestimable value.— They embark with him—cheer and comfort him in the perils and distresses of his voyage, and land him in happiness, and joy on the distant shore of his destination— I have never before heard Mr Lunt practice this style of composition; but the power of the parable is of such irresistible force in the discourses of Jesus Christ, that I have often wondered why it is not more frequently resorted to by the preachers of the gospel— A collection was taken up, to form the commencement of a parish library— Mr Lunt had given notice of it; and that this application would be made of it instead of purchasing books with it for the children of the Sunday Schools; and he requested contributions of books for the Library.— I read the 8th. Sermon of the 10th. Volume of Saurin on the greatness of God— The theme is too great for the exposition of mortal man.
7. IV. Monday.

Charles went in to Boston, and returned to dine— My attention to my seedling trees are now chiefly confined to those in the Seminary, where my success in sowing the seeds is hitherto more promising than it has been in the garden or the Nursery— The result of my experience however is, that the only fruit trees that can be raised to any purpose in this climate, without walls or hot houses, are Apples, Pears and Shagbark walnuts— Apricots, Nectarines, Cherries, Plums, and even peaches, I give up in despair—grapes are equally desperate; and I have little prospect of ever tasting the fruits even of my seedling apples and Pears— I worked this morning to remove some of the stones from two Seminary plats in the line of the old plum trees; and enlarging their borders. I received a Letter from Mr DuPonceau of Philadelphia, enclosing some abusive strictures upon my late Letter to William Foster, which he has published together with his Letter to me— In that Letter I spoke of the concerted suspension of specie payment by all the banks in terms such as I thought they deserved— The administration party have chuckled at this, because it gave them the opportunity to apply the censure which I made generall, to the Bank of the United States, and especially to my friend Nicholas Biddle.— The party views on both sides of this universal bankruptcy have no reference at all to the moral depravity involved in it; but to the political turn which may be given to it; and especially to its effect on the presidential election— The bank party in Philadelphia, are also flattering themselves that the Bank of the United States will be rechartered by Congress, and my Letter has no tendency to encourage them in this expectation. I began a reply to Mr DuPonceau, but could not finish it— Copeland was here this morning.
8. IV. Tuesday.

The morning was again wasted in labours upon my seminary plats, removing stones—enlarging borders, and attempting to fertilize with manure from the orchard Pond— Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston came by nine O’Clock— We went together to the probate Court, held by the judge Sherman Leland, and settled the third account of the Executors of the Will of Ward Nicholas Boylston— The first account had been settled in 1829. by the then judge Edward Hutchinson Robbins who died not long afterwards.— The second by this judge Leland at Dedham in 1831— The account has been kept—and was presented by Mr Curtis— The judge administered the oath to us all— Coming out, Mr Joseph Richards of Braintree stopped me, and said he wished to submit to me the claim of a poor and aged woman to a pension as the widow of a revolutionary soldier, and I told him I would readily take charge of it. After returning from the judge’s Court, we jointly executed a power, drawn up by Mr John Lowell to Joshua Bates, a copartner of the House of Baring and Co. in London, to receive from Petty Vaughan, any sums of money, due by him to us as Executors of W. N. Boylston’s Will; and to give him a discharge therefor— He has been more than seven years responsible to us, for upwards of ten thousand Pounds Sterling, which he has received, due to the Estate— He first involved it without a shadow of authority in the bankruptcy of his uncle William Vaughan; and since that resorts to every sort of prevarication to withhold the payment of the remnants which he has received in the form of dividends of William Vaughan’s estate. He has now by his own acknowledgment upwards of four thousand Pounds sterling deposited in a Banking House in exchequer Bills which it is his duty to remit to us, but which upon the shallowed pretences he retains— We have unfortunately, by the Law of England no compulsory controul over him— The
knave knows this and will never pay a farthing of the money— I proposed to Mr Curtis to draw a set of Bills upon him in favour of Mr Bates, for two thousand pounds, payable at ninety days sight, and enclose it with the power to Mr Bates—directing him if it should be paid to hold the money subject to be drawn for by us. I drafted Letters to Mr Bates and to Petty Vaughan accordingly; which Mr Curtis took with him, to write off, and send with the Bills to me for my signature; if upon consultation with Mr Lowell, and enquiry concerning the safety of Mr Bates, it should be expedient to forward the Bills— Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston dined with us, and returned after dinner to Roxbury— Evening unwell, with a dull head ache.
9. Wednesday. IV.

I plucked up this morning a willow stake, which I had stuck down about two years since towards the eastern end of the seminary, and which had taken root so strongly that it was not easily eradicated. After digging it up, I took out about a bushel of stones in the line across to the fence, which occupied my time till breakfast— A young man by the name of Aaron Adams junr. a merchant of Boston called and conversed with me about an hour, chiefly upon the political topics of the day. He had some weeks since written me a Letter upon the subject of Banks and Banking, which I had not answered; and from which he appears to be somewhat illiterate— I had intended to go to Boston this Morning to attend a Meeting of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences; but the weather was threatening, and I gave it up— There came up afterwards heavy rain which continued nearly through the day— I finished my Letter to Mr DuPonceau, and answered one from Caleb Cushing, and one from John Hardwick President of the Quincy Lyceum. The latter was to request me to deliver a Lecture, before that Society, and I was obliged to decline a similar invitation from Salem; and I have in both cases promised to perform the service in the course of the next year, if they should desire it, and I should be able— These Applications to deliver Orations, Addresses, and Lectures are exceedingly oppressive— I receive ten or a dozen of them, every year.— To write and deliver one a year absorbs all the time that I have in the intervals, between the Sessions of Congress; and it is an ungracious task to decline an invitation which carries a compliment with it— In the meantime my attention and my labours are withdrawn from the subject which ought to occupy them above all others.— First Althaea blossom.—
10. IV. Thursday

The Sun rose clear, precisely at 5. O’Clock, and I went over to Charles’s house and saw it rise from the southeastern chamber at the corner window overlooking the harbour— I marked the direction of its rising, which was over a shed north of the house standing at the corner junction of the Neponsit bridge turnpike and the County road. I dallied in the Seminary, by enlarging the border of the plat West of the two old Plum trees— I sowed the seeds of two ripe Jenneton pears, under the Pot-stand adjoining the chance planted Pear seedlings in front of the Althaea tree, west of my South-eastern front door— I received and answered a Letter from Benjamin Lundy, inviting me to address an Anti-Texas Meeting, on my way to Washington to attend the Session of Congress— I had already received the same invitation from Samuel Webb as Chairman of the Executive Committee of an Anti-Slavery Society in Philadelphia, and I had already an unanswered Letter from Benjamin Lundy, received nearly two Months since, inviting me to draft a memorial to Congress to be signed, against
the annexation of Texas to the Union— I have declined both. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. He brought me out a second Letter from James Savage, requesting a Letter of introduction for Mr George Ticknor to Genl Bernard— He wants it to send by a vessel to sail next Monday.
11. IV. Friday.

I have fallen into a habit of consuming the morning hours from rising to breakfast in bodily labour upon my grounds— This morning the whole time was occupied, in enlarging the borders round the Seminary plat where my granddaughter Fanny last year sowed the seeds—there are upon it ten seedling apple-trees, two pears and one cherry, one wild cherry, and three current bushes within a circle of 20 inches diameter—all looking puny, but as if with cultivation, they would live, and perhaps one or more of them prosper— I enlarged the circle to a diameter of nearly four feet, and dug out about two bushel baskets full of stones, the place of which I supplied with mould from the orchard pond— There were showers of rain— Mr Green, publisher of the Quincy Patriot, brought me an abusive Article, published in the Boston Centinel of last Wednesday, addressed to me, and which he said he had been requested to republish, but was unwilling to do it on accounts of its gross personalities, and it consists of nothing else. I read the article, and advised him to say in his paper of to-morrow that he had been requested to republish that Article, and would publish it, if the Author of the Letter would give his name— He said there was another person a Mr Goodrich who told him that he intended to reply to my Letter to William Foster— This is the author of the Peter Parley school-books— Green told me further that he had been censured for publishing the Article signed Philemon, in the last Saturday’s paper; on account of its personalities against Mr Whitney. I gave Mr Green the Boston Book of 1836. containing my Lines to a bereaved mother; correcting two errors of the press, that he might republish the lines in the next week’s paper— Mr Josiah Adams junr. this day finished the book shelves, and draws for books and papers in the farm house, and after dinner, I emptied three trunks of books and papers from Washington, and partly set them up; with the help of my five Grand-children— I wrote a Letter of introduction for Mr George Ticknor, to General Bernard at Paris.
12. V:45. Saturday.

I rose this morning nearly two hours later than my usual time, perhaps from having devoted more than usual of yesterday to bodily labour— The infirmities of age are thickening upon me, and especially since entering upon my 71st. year the daily warnings of a failing Constitution and decaying strength are multiplied in rapid succession— The showery morning confined me to the house, and the day was cold and cheerless— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine, and Mrs Frothingham was here this afternoon to visit her sister— Mrs Field, the Nurse of Charles’s youngest boy came out last Evening from Boston and is here— And Dr Woodward was called to visit Rachel our Cook, who is quite ill— I received a Letter from Mr Nathaniel Curtis with enclosures for Joshua Bates and Petty Vaughan, and a set of 3 bills of exchange for £2000 Sterling drawn upon Vaughan in favour of Bates— I brought up my Diary, which was running in arrear, and began to answer a Letter from Dr W. E. Channing
now at Newport, but could not finish it— Part of the day I was suffering with a rhumatic head ache— In the Evening however I walked with Charles to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where the young Ladies had been to take tea— Mrs Phineas Foster with her Sons George and Edward, and her daughter Fanny were there. Also Louisa C. Smith, unwell and Mrs Angier from Medford—Elizabeth C. and John Q. Adams the Midshipman— We rode home— Evening showery.
13. V:45. Sunday

Charles’s daughter Louisa Catherine’s birth-day— She is 6 years old— Heard Mr Lunt this morning from Romans 5.4. “And Patience Experience; and experience hope;” this was a discourse upon religious experience or experiences; with a tendency towards enthusiasm without falling into it— Mr Lunt inclines strongly to religious sensibilities as well as to intellectual piety, and it is perhaps in the combination of both that the perfection of religion consists— Reason leads us only along the paths of Justice, but the kindly feelings responsive to all good feeling, and indulgent to human frailty, are the properties most suitable, to man; himself a frail and erring creature— The afternoon Sermon, was from John 6.12— “He said unto his disciples, Gather up the fragments that remain, that nothing be lost”—an admirable text to illustrate the [“]virtue of frugality.”— And the preacher lost nothing which could be said upon it— He began by an allusion to a frequent error in supposing that an attentive regard to small things, is incompatible with the capacity to embrace great and important objects, and expatiated upon this memorable example of the reverse in the character of Jesus—contrasting that supernatural power which from five barley loaves and two small fishes could feed to satisfy five thousand persons, with that provident regard to the future, which instructed his disciples to gather the fragments that nothing might be lost— He marked the union of bountiful charity, connected with this frugal spirit, as a caution to beware of suffering the frugal principle to degenerate, as there is danger that it will, into parsimony, selfishness and avarice— The fragments were not to be gathered until every one had eaten to his full content— They were to be gathered, that nothing might be lost.— He referred to the success with which this virtue is generally attended in the world— To the common experience of how much it conduces to the worldly prosperity of him who practises it— To the kindred virtues with which it is usually accompanied, and to the vices, and excesses and ultimate ruin which so often follows the disregard and neglect of it— This was the most practical sermon that I have heard from Mr Lunt— I read the 9th. Sermon of the 10th Volume of Saurin; upon the renewal of the world, and thought of writing a Lyceum Lecture upon the nature and obligation of promises. Whether I shall ever fulfil this promise to myself will hereafter appear— I finished the Letter, begun yesterday to Doctor W. E. Channing.— My wife was unwell this afternoon and Evening.
14. V. Monday

My three grand-daughters sowed in the garden, Jenneton Pear-seeds, withered cherries, and crushed black currants in one row, in the garden, from the embanked old Pear trees western-end, Northward towards the fence; with stakes separating the three divisions. Mary-Louisa, between Fanny Southward, and Louisa Catherine Northward— Mary-Louisa, also sowed jenneton pear-seeds and black currant seeds in the Seminary plat where there are now five puny apple seedlings, from seeds sown last October. I emptied a fourth trunk from Washington, and set up the books in the small chamber of the Farm-house— Mr Thomas Houghton of Bolton in the County of Worcester came to make some enquiries, concerning his claim for a pension, on account of the services in the revolutionary war, of his father Joseph Houghton— He said that Governor Lincoln, presented a petition for him to the House of Representatives at the last Session of Congress; but there was not time to act upon it— He had promised to call it up at the next Session, and had told him that he would rely upon my support to carry it through— I assured him that he might depend upon it so far as would be consistent with my sense of duty— He spoke of other subjects—upon the currency with bitterness against the Banks— Of Abolition, which he said was rapidly spreading in his part of the State. He said he had heard the Misses Grimké lecture last Evening at Boxborough— Mr Minott Thayer came afterwards, and had also a claim for a pension for a Mrs Allen a widow of a revolutionary soldier long since deceased, and who is insane— She has children, and I told Mr Thayer that they must petition for her, and if her case is such as Congress may be inclined to provide for, she must have a legal guardian, to be accountable for the money— Mr Thayer complained very much of ill-treatment from Mr B. F. Hallett—and was quite uneasy upon two subjects— One the distribution by the towns of Weymouth and Braintree; of the money which by the Acts of Congress was placed in deposit in the several States, and which by Acts of the Legislature of this Commonwealth, have been ordered to be distributed among the towns throughout the State— The town of Weymouth voted to dole it out in loans, at one per Cent interest to all the inhabitants of the Town, and Mr Thayer had a printed pamphlet containing opposite opinions of Peleg Sprague and Benjamin F. Hallett as lawyers, on the question whether this disposal of the money was lawful; Sprague holding that it was; not: and Hallett that it was— There is also a pugnacious report of the Committee of the Town; sent to confer with the Treasurer of the State concerning the payment of the money. Thayer said Braintree would follow the example of Weymouth— That a town meeting for the same purpose at Randolph; and he thought it would also be adopted by the town of Quincy— The other subject of Mr Thayer’s concern, was the meeting here, proposed for next Wednesday week, which he said he and many others feared was to be an abolition Meeting in disguise. He told me something of the manner in which it was gotten up, and was much delighted when I informed him that I should probably not attend the Meeting. My
My wife was ill, confined to her bed the whole of this day— Mary and Charles’s wife went after dinner to Weymouth; and spent an hour of the Evening with Fanny Beale, irrecoverably gone in a consumption—a most affecting and melancholy case.
15. V. Tuesday.

Charles and his wife went to Boston this morning and returned to dine— Deacon William Spear called and paid me 219 dollars for Mr Job Faxon, for my pew N. 75 in the Stone Meeting house. He told me that two lots of woodland adjoining mine in the 600 Acre woods, were to be sold at auction in November as part of the Estate of Darius Boardman deceased, who married my uncle Peter B’s daughter Susanna, through whom he acquired this land—and asked me, if I should wish to purchase it— I said I had not the means of paying for it— Mr Spear complained much of the impossibility of procuring money, and of the refusal of the banks to pay specie— He said Asaph Churchill of Milton had been to the Quincy Stone Bank with, its bills to the amount of 75 dollars, for which he demanded specie— The Cashier Ibrahim Bartlett, told him his orders were not to pay specie— Churchill pressed him for some time, and finally proposed to compound, if he would give him twenty dollars of the money in specie, and Bartlett did it upon his own responsibility— Mrs Briesler was here to enquire whether she could claim the continuance to her of a Pension, which her husband the late John Briesler received for service in the revolutionary War— I read to her the third Section of the Act of 4 July 1836. by which she saw that she had no claim—her marriage having taken place, after the close of the War— She said Mrs. Spear who applied to me some time since, had assured her that she was certain of obtaining her pension, although she was not married till long after the War— I said I had told Mrs Spear that she had no claim under the act of 1836. Mrs Briesler said Mrs. Spear had acknowledged this, but she was nevertheless confident of obtaining the Pension, though she was rich, and did not want it— I called at the Bank and exchanged Mr Curtis’s draught on the Tremont Bank and the Bills which I had received from Job Faxon, for Bills of the Bank of the United States— I made some enquiries concerning the condition of the Bank, and a statement of its condition was shewn me, of the last and several preceding Saturdays— I asked for a copy of the last, and also of the act of incorporation of the Bank which Mr Bartlett the Cashier promised me. Harvey Field, one of the Directors of the Bank was there; and the President Lemuel Bartlett came in while I was there— I went also to the printing Office of the Quincy Patriot, and took a paper of the 24th. of June, containing the Pension Laws of 4. July 1836 and 3. March 1837, and the regulations of the War Department for carrying them into execution— I told Mr Green that I should probably not attend the meeting here on the 23d. instt. thinking it would be somewhat indelicate, as the purpose of the meeting was to pass resolutions relating to my own conduct at the last Session of Congress— He said they would pass the Resolutions and send a Committee to me with them and to invite my attendance while the subject of the annexation of Texas should be considered— I said I thought I should decline attending, wishing to avoid all that might disturb the harmony of the People of the District.— He told me that Mr Brackett
the President, and Josiah Brigham, one of the directors of the Quincy Stone-bank had again urged him to republish the abusive Letter addressed to me, and published in the Boston Centinel of last Wednesday— I said I had no objection to his republishing it; but I thought if he did, he should say that it was at the request of the President and one of the Directors of the Quincy Bank. Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us.
16. V. Wednesday.

Plucked up the willow stake at the Eastern end of the Seminary, and took out half a bushel of stones from near the surface— I had also the willow trees in the garden taken up, which I had staked out in 1832— I have enough of that experiment— The common willow is of the weed nature, fitter to be uprooted than planted. Mr Ezra Dyer was here with Mr Peter Dyer to enquire concerning the claim of his mother in Law, Mrs Thayer, widow of Philip Thayer for a pension— He was pensioned by the act of June 1832. but died a short time after— Her papers are at Washington, or with judge Leland. I called at the Bank, and Mr Bartlett gave me a copy of the Act of incorporation, and a statement of the condition of the Bank up to last Evening. I asked him also for a list of the Stockholders of the Bank at this time; which he promised me, and a list of the Directors. At the Office of the Quincy Patriot, I desired Mr Green to republish the Letter to me in the Centinel, and to inform Mr Brackett, and Mr Brigham, that I had desired it, on being informed that they had requested it— I also told him, that if requested to attend the meeting here next Wednesday I would attend; but I wished it to be understood, that I should prefer not to be invited; and that I thought it would be most advisable both for the cause of those who would hold the Meeting and for myself, that I should not attend. John Quincy Adams, the Midshipman, and John Foster were here this morning— Mary dined at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and Charles’s wife went there after dinner to tea. Mr Price Greenleaf came this afternoon, and rambled with me over my Garden, Nursery and seminary— I consulted with him concerning my small seedlings, sorely afflicted with Aphides he counseled washing their top shoots with Salaeratus and water. I despatched the Letters to Petty Vaughan, and Joshua Bates, with the set of 3 Bills of exchange on Vaughan for £2000 to Mr Nathaniel Curtis—and received 12 Copies of my Oration of 4. July at Newbury-Port from the publishers Morss and Brewster— My wife is convalescent.
17 IV.30. Thursday

I sowed a cross row of Jenneton pear seeds at the eastern end of the seminary— The seedlings in the pots from the Jenneton pears have the healthiest appearance of any that have come up— The jargonels are now so nearly ripe that some lover of fruit in the neighbourhood nearly stripp’d one of our trees of its load— I had the rest gathered— Three of my budded pear trees bear this year for the first time— The Dearborn, Harvard andFrench washed the trees that have gathered moss with Potash and Water. Deacon Spear was here this morning, and told me of a new petition for a road from Braintree to the
the Rail way quarries, and which will not pass through my lands. He said that the town had received a notification to attend a meeting of the county commissioners for a survey, on the tenth of next Month— He thought the town would be opposed to laying out this road— I agreed to go with Mr Spear next Tuesday afternoon at half past 3. O’Clock to see the lot of woodland on pine-hill, which I purchased last October of Samuel Copeland junr— My wife, with Mary and Charles’s wife went to Boston this afternoon to take tea with Mrs Frothingham—returned home just before the bell rang for nine— An old clergyman by the name of Jotham Sewall 77 years of age called to see me this afternoon— He said he had once called on me before, when I was Secretary of War, or some such thing— He was then going to South Carolina; but now comes from the State of Maine; and is about to return thither— Mr Silsbee and his two daughters also paid me a visit, on their way to New-Bedford. He said he came round by this way, on purpose to call upon me— He has within a year or two lost his wife— I removed some books and papers to the small chamber in the farmhouse; but shall not be able to finish that work, before I shall be obliged to go to Washington— Played Loto with Charles and the three little girls, in the Evening— I find I cannot write after dark.
18. IV. Friday— Charles’s birth-day—30.

The Jenneton Pears are now over ripe, and the seedlings from seeds of that pear which I sowed last summer, and which have come up are healthier than any others, and have taken no blight— I intend to sow them in large quantities now, for the chances of next Summer— I put in six Cores this morning under the Pot stands, between the Western Althaea tree and the gate— There was a cluster of 8 seedling pears from one whole pear or core towards the eastern end of the seminary— I took out seven of them, six of which I immediately set out in cross row, to where I plucked up some days since the willow stake; and one close to the eastern fence— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. Sultry, misty, drizzling day— Sent over a few books and papers to the farm house. Received 200 copies of the Newbury-Port Oration— Answered a Letter from Dr Waterhouse, and wrote 2 pages of the biography of my mother.
19. IV:15. Saturday

I planted 48 whole decaying Jenneton Pears in a row fronting the Nursery fence, and Eastward of the gate— French is opening a new row of 8 Stools for transplanted fruit trees in the Seminary— This is the fifth row, besides the border rows North and South— The row in the line with the two old Plum trees, and the seminary bed fronting the Northern fence. My transplanted trees: Peach, Cherry, and black walnut promise me poor returns, and after ten years of experiments to raise fruit trees from the seed— I have hitherto had my labour for my pains— Yet I persevere, though I should need another life of sixty years, to bring my plantations to a successful result. President Quincy paid me a morning visit— The university is now in vacation. Commencement next Wednesday week, the day after that on which I propose to depart for
for Washington. Mr Quincy said the condition of the University was quite satisfactory, and the conduct of the students, for the last two years had been exemplary; but he was evidently anxious on account of the small numbers of the students and said they wanted beneficiary funds— He said that twenty-thousand dollars a year, were expended by individuals for the education of children at Yale College, for the sake of orthodoxy, and he had received only two days since Letters from two Clergymen desirous of placing their sons at Cambridge, but enquiring how much assistance they could receive from the beneficiary funds— He said the Divinity and Law schools were flourishing. Mr Thomas Loring of Hingham was here, and spoke of the meeting to be held here next Wednesday which he expected to attend— He was earnest in the expression of his aversion to the admission of Texas into the Union—said that he was no abolitionist, but if Texas should be palmed upon us, he believed he should be driven to it. He appeared to be desirous that subject of the currency should also be considered at the meeting next Wednesday, and very earnest that I should attend the meeting. The Revd. Mr Bradley Miner, a baptist clergyman, who has recently opened a School, at the House built for an Hotel on this side of Neponset bridge was here; and left me a prospectus of his establishment, which is called the Dorchester High school— He said he had now fourteen scholars, 4 from this and 10 from the other side of the Bridge— That he now preaches on Sundays at the House, but they are about building a meeting house in the Neponset village in Dorchester. I sent some books and papers over to the farm house, but am too much straitened for time to accomplish this work before the Meeting of Congress— I answered Letters from Robert Gilmor of Baltimore, and Samuel Webb, of Philadelphia. Warm day— Bathed with Charles at one P.M— Swam 5 minutes— High Tide. Midshipman John Q. Adams and George Foster were here this morning— Mary and Charles’s wife visited in the Evening at Mr Beale’s. The beautiful flower, his second daughter is withering upon the stalk.
20. V.12. Sunday—with the rising Sun—

Dr Parkman of Boston was the preacher— His morning text was from Ephesians 4.28. “Let him that stole, steal no more: but rather let him labour, working with his hands the thing which is good, that he may have to give to him that needeth.” I had been very much pleased, with a sermon upon this text by Doctor Follen, last Spring at Washington, (9. April) and was equally delighted with the Discourse of this day, excepting the doubt whether a little stealing had not been practiced of the materials to make it up— The treatment of the subject was the same—Honesty—Industry—Charity—an enlargement of the literal meaning of the injunction to discontinue stealing so as to include all injustice and wrong—the connection between the virtues of industry and Charity, and the admirable morality of the Apostle, in thus recommending them
them in unison. The doctrine and argument of the two Sermons was precisely the same; but the composition was so different, that I should not even have been reminded of Dr Follen’s discourse by any resemblance of it in the details of Dr Parkman’s; which was precisely such as I could myself have written upon that text after hearing Dr Follen— Dr. Parkman’s afternoon text was from Psalm 37.25. [“]I have been young and now am old; yet have I not seen the righteous forsaken, nor his seed begging bread.” There was much allusion towards the close of this discourse, to the present disordered state of our public affairs, and to the distresses of the community— And the auditory were reminded of all the blessings that as a Nation we still enjoy— Of the contrast between our condition, and that of Nations visited with the great calamities of War, Pestilence or famine; and he exhorted his hearers to sentiments of peace, of harmony and of mutual benevolence. The sermon in this respect was well-timed, and well received.— Dr Parkman dined with us. He told me that his brother George with his family have arrived at New-York, and will be at Boston, next Tuesday— We had for evening visitors Coll. Josiah Quincy junr. Mr Degrand with Mr Peddrick and Mr Clapp, editor of the Evening Gazette, Elizabeth C. Adams and Hannah Miller, with George Foster and Charles Miller— I read the 10th. Sermon of the 10th volume of Saurin upon the great, as contrasted with the small duties of religion.
21. III:45. Monday.

I labour every morning from my rising nearly till breakfast, with my hands— This morning I enlarged the border round the plat where Fanny sowed seeds last Fall, and where her seedlings are now growing— John Quincy Adams, the Midshipman was here. My wife, with Mary, Charles and his wife, went this afternoon to Roxbury to visit and take tea with Mrs Boylston— While they were gone, Mrs Abbott Lawrence, with her two daughters Miss Lincoln, and two other Misses were here. Mrs Lawrence apologized for her husband, who was obliged by a sudden call, to go this day to New-York— Mr Fletcher, the Representative-elect of Boston to Congress also left Boston this day for Washington— I wasted much of this day in idleness, and in the Evening played Loto with the children
22. III:30. Tuesday

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— I laboured the morning before breakfast away, in enlarging the border, round the plat in the Seminary West of Fanny’s, and between the two old Plum trees— I dug a trench round it, and took out half a bushel of stones—then filled the trench with a mixture of mud from the orchard pond, and garden mould— The eight new plats opened two feet deep in the seminary, and from which about forty bushels of stones have been removed, were this day also filled up with fresh earth— Mr Dugan the collector of the taxes called on me this day, but said he would cheerfully wait my convenience for payment— I told him that having now a special call, by the summons to attend a special of Congress, I must postpone the present payment of the tax, but referred him to my Son for payment at an early day— Deacon Spear came according to our agreement at 1/2 past three this afternoon, and I rode with him, first to the woodlot on pine hill which I purchased last October of S. Copeland jr. six acres and a fraction, from which the wood had then just been cut off— It adjoins the Baxter
lot, and has a growth of Oaks sprung up this Season, and of promising appearance— From thence we went over the newly opened road to the railway house, and then by the other new road to the Captain’s Bridge. We turned off from this to see the spot of the old furnace, and the dam which excluded the Water of a small pond— There are still remnants of furnace cinders and burnt bricks on the spot.— We then went and took up Josiah Adams at his house; and went and viewed the ground through which a third new road is petitioned for by certain inhabitants of Braintree, from this side their Meeting house to the Railway house— It will run through my land, at two different places— This is the road to be viewed by the County Commissioners in September, and which it is said will be strenuously opposed by the town of Quincy. On returning home I went up to Charles’s House, and saw the sun set at 6:45. Mr Ayer the contracting Carpenter was there, and said he should finish and clear out to-morrow: As I went back to my house I met Mr William Ellis of Dedham who came to make enquiries concerning certain persons having claims on account of the prize, taken by the Alliance Frigate in Paul Jones’s squadron in 1779. and also concerning the Pension Law in favour of the widows of revolutionary soldiers. I promised to give him information of what should be done in Congress on these subjects— He took tea with us— Professor Palfrey and his wife were here this afternoon while I was out.
23. IV:30. Wednesday.

A morning light and Sunrise of surpassing beauty. I went over to Charles’s house and from the South-East corner window of the chamber saw the Sun rise 5:16. and marked its southing in line with the middle of the Southern gate— The prospect was enchanting— There was a ship under full sail entering the harbour, and just within the light house point— The Ex-deacon Josiah Adams was here immediately after breakfast; and sat with me upwards of an hour— Mr Thomas Loring of Hingham came next— The District Convention of delegates from the towns of the 12th. Congressional district of Massachusetts, convened to pass resolutions, approving of my conduct at the last Session of Congress, in the discussions upon the right of petition, and against the annexation of Texas to the United States, was held this day at the town-Hall— They met at 9. O’Clock this morning, all the towns of the District being represented but three—Hull,—Milton—andThey passed unanimously certain Resolutions; against the Resolution of the late House of Representatives of the 18th. of January last, and approving in terms of the warmest commendation my course in the House at the last Session; not only for the substance, but for the manner. Also a Resolution to appoint a Committee of Correspondence, and two Resolutions assigning reasons against the annexation of Texas to the United States— They then adjourned from one to half past two O’Clock, after appointing a Committee of five to communicate the adopted resolutions to me, and to request my attendance at the adjournment of their meeting in the afternoon— Mr Thomas Greenleaf who presided at the meeting called on me and gave me notice that the Committee were coming— They came at 2 O’Clock and delivered to me
me a copy of the Resolutions, for which I desired them to return my thanks, and to say that in compliance with their invitation I would attend the meeting at 3. O’Clock, which I accordingly did— I went alone—the Committee met me at the door of the Hall; and the President presented me to the meeting— I addressed them for about an hour and a half on their Resolutions— I was frequently interrupted by cheering applause, and although my speech was far below mediocrity it was very favourably received— Mr May then moved that some poetical lines which he had read, written by Mr Pierpont of Boston, should be published with the proceedings of the meeting which was agreed to without opposition— The meeting was then dissolved and notice was given that at 1/2 past 7 O’Clock this evening, the Revd. Samuel J. May would deliver a Lecture on the right of petition— A number of copies of the pamphlet edition of my Letters to the inhabitants of the 12th. Congressional district were gratuitously distributed— Mr Harvey Field introduced to me, Deacon Sullivan of Germantown, and Mr H. B. Stanton, who said he wished to have some conversation with me, and whom I told I would see him if it should suit his convenience at my house the day after to-morrow— Deacon Sullivan said he had read with great satisfaction my Anti-masonic Letters— I walked home with Mr Thomas Greenleaf and Russell Freeman—who gave me a bundle of papers, being recommendations of him, for the appointment of Collector at the port of New-Bedford, which he wishes me to present to the Secretary of the Treasury. He came on from Sandwich this morning and after his interview with me proceeded to Boston— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came, and budded for me five apple trees from slips brought this morning from Hingham, by Mr Loring, and given to me— They are of a large, pleasant acid apple which he says ripen by the middle of July—from a tree imported by Eben Parsons when he Loring was about 14 years old—he then took a slip from it, which has now become a large tree and bears plentifully— I budded with it four young stocks in the garden, and one in the nursery— Ann Beale and Louisa Wales were here in the Evening, and Mr Beale came for them— Some mischievous fellow kindled a fire, in the shavings from Charles’s house, which he had removed to some distance from it—the object was to make an alarm of fire, to break up Mr May’s Lecture which it effectually did— The Bells rang for some time, and Charles was out without his hat nearly two hours, to watch the blazing and dying off of the flames— Mr Loring had brought from Hingham a series of Resolutions, upon the subject of the currency, banking, and the suspension of specie payments, which he intended to present to the meeting—he shewed them to me; and I assented to all of them but two— These he determined to strike out; but he finally concluded not to offer them—
24— III:45 Thursday
Boston— Dr Frothinghams—return to Quincy.

I went into Boston with Charles. Stopp’d at Deacon James H. Foster’s. Saw Mrs Foster and Elizabeth— The family are in great distress— Mary is at Brookline, dying of a marasmus— William is about dying after nearly a year of insanity— Mrs Foster, told me that last week he was so ill that they did not expect he
he would have lived to this time; and now they had no hope of his recovery. Louisa is with Mary— My next call was at Governor Everett’s, and with him I got engaged in conversation, till he reminded me that there was an adjourned meeting of the Overseers of the University at half past 12— I went with him to the State-house— The meeting was in the Senate chamber— It was merely to receive and approve the report of a Committee upon the nominations for Doctors of Divinity and one honorary Master of Arts— The report was made by Benjamin Russell, Chairman of the Committee and now a member of the Council; was immediately accepted, and the Meeting was adjourned to commencement morning at Cambridge— I then went to my Son’s Office where I found Russell Freeman, still labouring with solicitude for his papers and for the Office of Collector at New-Bedford— After some conversation with him he decided to leave all his papers with me. I went to the agency of the Bank of the United States 70. State-Street. Mr Frothingham gave me an order on the State-Bank, for the order of 170 Dollars on him which I had brought from Philadelphia— I gave him to examine the Bills which Mr Bartlett had given me at the Quincy Bank; he found them all good but one ten dollar bill which he said was counterfeit— They paid me the order at the State Bank— I stopp’d at Deacon James H. Foster’s shop, and saw him and his son Charles.— He paid me 22 dollars a dividend of two dollars a share on 11. shares, in the Braintree and Weymouth turnpike.— I then called at a Booksellers and purchased a Bible for a birth-day present to my Grand-daughter Louisa Catherine— Dined at Dr Frothingham’s— Mr P. C. Brooks, his son Sidney with his wife Mr Stetson of Medford, and Mr Hedge, unsettled, Governor and Mrs Everett, with Charles and myself constituted the company— After dinner My wife, with Mary, and Mrs Charles came in from Quincy to tea—immediately after which, Charles and I returned to Quincy. The Ladies followed us late in the evening.— In the evening Josiah Adams junr was here, and I made some progress towards a settlement of accounts with him but did not finish. I received a Letter from Revd. Samuel J. May, Orin P. Bacon, and J. A. Green, publishing Committee of the District Convention held here yesterday requesting me to write out for publication my Speech of yesterday afternoon— Ezra Dyer was here yesterday; and left a paper relating to the pension claim of the children of Philip Thayer’s widow—but I was engaged with Mr Loring and could only tell Mr Dyer that I would attend to the claim at Washington
25. IV. Friday

The English Jenneton pears have lasted from the first of this month— The Jargonelles from the 15th. The Catherine Pears are just now ripening— I called after breakfast at the bank, and Mr Bartlett the Cashier, took back the ten dollar Bill, of the Bank of the United States which Mr Frothingham had pronounced counterfeit, and gave me one of the Quincy Stone Bank in exchange— He gave me also a list of the present Stockholders of the bank— I then went to the printing Office and told Mr Green that I had received
received the Letter from the publishing Committee of the proceedings of the Convention of last Wednesday, requesting me to write out for publication, the remarks made by me at the meeting— That I would do it if possible; but was now so much engaged in preparations for my departure that I could not do it for some time— That in publishing the proceedings in the paper to-morrow, he might say that he would publish my Speech at a future day— He shewed me his own account of the proceedings, which was not long— I told him that I might probably write to him from Washington— After dinner Mr Eliphaz Thayer was here, respecting a claim for a pension, and a young man by the name of Charles Stark Newell, a grandson of John Stark of Bennington brought me a Letter of introduction from Doctor Waterhouse. He was graduated at Cambridge in 1835 and told me he was going to Washington where he would call on me again— Joseph H. Adams was with him— In the Evening Josiah Adams junr. came again, and we settled the account of the balance due to him, upon the contract for building a house at Mount Wollaston and other work; but wanting to refer to a partial settlement made with him last fall which I had not this day been able to find, I asked him to call again to-morrow evening.
26. III:30. Saturday.

My planting, this Season is confined to the seeds of the Jenneton pear, and this morning I planted from one to four in each of the plats in the six rows of eight each, in the seminary—and I gave plats to each of the children to call their own— Minott Thayer was here to speak about a widow’s pension claim— The very singular case of Captain Joseph Allen— Mr Thayer was taking depositions in support of his claim under the act of 1832. and he had just signed his own declaration, when he was seized with a fit, and died— The widow, is, and has been many years insane; and the petition to Congress is now signed by her five children— Mr Thayer spoke with great satisfaction of the recent convention and its result— His visit was followed by that of Mr Lemuel Humphrey of Weymouth, who left with me statements of the claims of three widows—Lucy Holbrook, Olive Lovell, and Ruth Bates, all widows of revolutionary Soldiers, and claiming pensions under the act of 4. July 1836— Mr and Mrs S. B. Barrell from Boston paid us a morning visit and Thomas K Davis son of Isaac P. Davis came out and dined with us. Joseph H. Adams came alone in a Gig, from Charlestown where he is stationed as a midshipman, to ask me for money— I had none to give him, and his visit was short.— Josiah Adams junr. came in the evening, and I made a final settlement with him, and gave him a check on the bank for the balance due to him— I received this day a Letter from Mr Nicholas Biddle, cordially inviting me to his house on my way to Washington, and alluding delicately to a passage of my Letter to William Foster lately published, which has maliciously been applied as a severe reflection upon him— This paragraph has exated inextinguishable wrath in all the President’s and Directors of the Banks throughout the Union.
27. IV:30. Sunday.

Mr Whitney preached this morning, from Deuteronomy 32:47. “For it is not a vain thing for you: because it is your life” upon the doctrine of future retribution— The argument was to prove the punishment hereafter for sins committed in the present life— Immediately after the morning service, I saw that Mr John Peter De Wint was there— He came home with me, and will stay some days here— His son John Peter and his daughter Anna Maria were at school at Mr John Angiers at Medford: and his daughters Elizabeth, and Isabella came on with him.— In the afternoon Mr Lunt preached from 1. Corinthians 12.21. [“]And the eye cannot say unto the hand, I have no need of thee: nor again the head to the feet, I have no need of you.” The Discourse was a sort of abridgement of my oration at Newbury-Port—rather carelessly written— He gave out the 194th. hymn of Dr. Belknap’s collection—“Oer mountain tops”—which at my request was sung at Newbury-Port— I read the 11th Sermon of the 10th. volume of Saurin, on the small duties of Religion. The counterpart of the preceding Sermon on the great duties— The second is a fragment, the introductory part of the discourse having been lost— Mr De Grand came from Boston for an afternoon visit, and Elizabeth C. Adams, John and Frank Foster and Isabella and Anna Maria De Wint were here in the Evening. Walked with De Grand to Charles’s House and saw the Sun set.
28. III:40. Monday

The Sun rose clear, with an atmosphere of unusual splendour. I went to my Son’s house and saw the rise 23 minutes past 5. from the east corner of the House, in a line with the Southern post of the South gate. I planted a circular row of decayed jenneton Pears round the plot, in the centre of which is a Philadelphia Maple seedling, between the two old plum-trees in the Seminary— Deacon Spear was here, and spoke of the woodlot to be sold by the heirs of Darius Boardman, whose first wife was my uncle Peter Boylston Adams’s daughter Susanna, by whom he had children— He afterwards had a second wife, and last Winter drowned himself— His administrator proposes to sell first the wood standing on the lot which came to his heirs, by the right of his first wife, and then the land itself and said to Mr Spear that he would be willing to take for the land 29 dollars an Acre— I told Mr Spear I should not be willing to give so much as that, but might give twenty— The are about 21 acres of it, in two lots one of 17, and one of 4. Acres.— Mr Joseph Richards of Braintree was here, and spoke of some widow pension claim, and also of the District Convention, held here last week, convened principally by his exertions, and which he said had resulted entirely to his satisfaction— To me, the result of this Convention will depend wholly upon my discretion at the ensuing Session of Congress, and I think of it under a sense of deep and heavy responsibility— At this moment the popular voice of the District, is so strong in my favour, that no other voice is heard— Within one year, the unanimity may be reversed— It is not in man that walketh to direct his steps—may mine be directed from above.— Mr James Newcomb was also here, and brought me 50 copies of Mr Charles Brooks’s address here at Quincy on the 4th. of July last— Visits to take leave from Mr Whitney and Mr Lunt; and from Mrs.
Mrs T. B. Adams, and her family— This was the distressing day previous to that of departure, and it grows more and more irksome to me at every repetition.
29. III:45. Tuesday
Boston— Providence— Steamer Massachusetts. Long-Island Sound.

I left Quincy at 8 this morning and went into Boston with Charles— Sent my trunk, cloak and carpet bag, by Gillet, who promised to send them before one to the Providence railway depot— In Boston, I was going to call on Dr. George Parkman, when I met Mr Abbott Lawrence in the Street, and he took me with him to his house, where I had with him a conversation of nearly two hours— He has just returned from an excursion to New-York and Philadelphia— Three of the deposit Banks at New-York have issued a circular inviting a convention of all the banks, to consult about a simultaneous resumption of Specie payments— Mr Lawrence told me, that neither the Philadelphia, nor the Boston Banks would comply with this invitation of the New-York Banks— He also told me that Mr Nicholas Biddle was under the impression, which he did not share, that the Executive Government of the United States would be compelled, and were already disposed to return to the Bank of the United States, for the collection and disbursement of the revenue— Mrs Lawrence was at Nahant— Mrs Andrew Bigelow came in while I was there— As did Mr John Reed, my colleague in the House of Representatives of the United States.— After leaving Mr Lawrence, I met in the street and spoke with Mr N. L. Frothingham the Minister— I attended at Noon the Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society but was obliged very soon to leave it, and repair to the Rail-road Cars for Providence— At one O’Clock they started— My Son took leave of me as they departed— We reached Providence at 1/2 past 3. and by 4. left the wharf in the Steam boat Massachusetts—Captain Comstock, who was not on board— Touched at Newport just after six— Mr Nathaniel Curtis, with his wife, and Mrs Boylston, were passengers with me so far, from Boston— They disembarked at Newport— Mr Daniel Webster and Mr Stephen White, as well as Mr John Reed were likewise fellow passengers and Mr George Evans of Maine.— This was the day of Election, in Rhode-Island, for members of the State Legislature, and for members of the House of Representatives of the United States for the 25th. Congress. Both at Providence and at Newport there was much exultation at the success of the whigs—there being considerable majorities in both towns; and no doubt of the election of Tillinghast and Cranston to Congress; instead of Dutee J. Pearce, and Sprague who declined. This reverse is not favourable to the administration of Martin van Buren— At Newport Mr Asher Robbins one of the U.S. Senators from Rhode Island, joined us as a passenger The passage round point Judith was uncommonly smooth. The weather fine; but with a rising Southwest wind, swelling almost to a gale. We had nearly reached the Falkner’s Island light when I went to bed— Mr Webster spoke quite affably to me, two or three times. Mr Abbott Lawrence had expressed a wish to me that we should be reconciled; and said he had once negotiated a Peace between Webster and Clay—
30. V. Wednesday.
New York— Rockaway, Long-Island.

We had 370. passengers in the Steamboat Massachusetts; and crowded as they all were into the Cabin births and cots, the heat was so excessive that I could not sleep a wink— We landed at New-York at 8 O’Clock this morning, and I came and took a chamber at the Astor-house— It was full, and I could obtain a chamber only by waiting until some of the lodgers went away— Immediately after breakfast, Mr Charles A. Davis called on me, and proposed to me, to go with him to Rockaway, to which I assented. Coll. Hamilton heretofore keeper of an inn at Framingham, then of the exchange tavern at Boston—afterwards of the Washington House at New-York, called and informed me, that a Committee from the American Institute were desirous of waiting upon me, and I agreed to receive them at 11 O’Clock— They came at that time— Hamilton was among them; as were Samuel L. Knapp, Dudley Marvin, and four or five others whose names escaped me— Their object was to request me to deliver an Address before the members of the Institute, sometime in October next— I fear it will be utterly impossible, and so informed them; but I promised that I would if I could— It has so churlish an appearance positively to reject these solicitations, that I have no heart to do it, and yet they are so multiplied that it is impossible for me to comply with one of them in ten— At Noon Mr Davis came— I walked with him to the ferry at the corner of the Battery— There we met a Mr M’Nabb, whom Mr Davis introduced to me as Speaker of the House of Assembly of the British province of upper Canada, who was also going to Rockaway, where his family were— A very good looking Gentleman, and a loyal conservative; for within 5 minutes he assured me, that His Majesty, had no more loyal Subjects than the people of Upper Canada— We crossed the ferry to Brookline; there took the Railway Cars, through Jamaica, to Bedford; where the railway terminates— Mr Davis’s chaise was there at a tavern; and in it I rode with him to Rockaway, 20 Miles from New-York, and on the Eastern shore of Long Island. We found there Mrs Davis—Judge Wayne of the Supreme Court of the United States—Mr M’Nabb’s family, Mr Richard Bayard, and Mr Clinton of New-York a son of the late Governor De Witt Clinton— It was the warmest day I had experienced this Summer. Just at Sunset I walked down to the beach with Mr Davis, and took a bath with the surf breaking over me— I had barely time to dress and return to the house when there came up from the west, a dark, but not heavy thunder shower— Spent the evening in conversation with Mr and Mrs Davis, judge and Mrs Wayne, Mr Bayard and Mr. Clinton—
31. V. Thursday
New-York— Philadelphia— Marshall House

At 5 this morning, Mr Davis was ready with his Chaise; and we departed: stopp’d a quarter of an hour at Bedford and, crossing the ferry
ferry from Brookline to the Fulton slip, he landed me at the Astor-House, just in time to breakfast and to reach the Steamer for Amboy at 9.— I met at the Astor House Governor Gibbs of Newport, who had been there from New-York for the single purpose of voting at the election, and had returned with us in the Massachusetts— He now told me that the passengers in the Lexington which arrived this morning brought the news that the whigs Tillinghast and Cranston had been elected to Congress by a majority of more than a thousand votes over D. J. Pearce and Howard— He told me too that the Lexington last Night in Providence river, before reaching Newport, had been very nearly overset by a violent thundergust— That two sloops had been actually capsized in her sight, and that she had saved the people of one of them excepting two women in her cabin who were drowned— The Steamboat for Amboy was crowded with more than two hundred passengers— The first man I met upon going on board, was C. C. Cambreleng, who accosted me laughing, and said that he and I were in the same box about the Banks— Ely Moore, Atherton of New-Hampshire, Legaré of South-Carolina, Haley and Ingham of Connecticut, Reuel Williams Senator, Evans a Representative from Maine, and several other Members of Congress were in the Boat— It was long before I could get my ticket for the Cars, and the Captain was so grossly uncivil to me, that I came too nigh quarreling with him— He gave me in revenge a ticket for the worst car in the train— H.N.S. an open waggon, and it was pouring with rain— The conductor however gave me a Seat in the best of the Cars, that reserved for the use of the Invalids, where my fellow passengers were a man with his arm in a sling, who was well nigh killed by the Bowsprit of a Schooner running through the Cabin window of the Steam boat Lexington, and thrusting him out of his birth with his collar bone broken his shoulder dislocated, and his breath crushed out of his body.— His wife was with him— Mr Meredith of Baltimore, a fellow passenger in the boat, had been kindly solicitous to get me a seat in the Car with him but I was well provided for— On landing at Philadelphia I went immediately to Mr Nicholas Biddle’s house, but was told by the Maid servant who came to the door, that he had been taken suddenly ill this afternoon after dinner and that the Doctor was with him— My trunk, bag and cloak were however taken to my chamber Mr Biddle’s Son Charles soon after came in, and appeared to be in considerable anxiety— I asked him to consult the Doctor, whether it might not be better that his father should not see me this evening, and this was the Doctor—Laroches advice— I therefore went and engaged a bedchamber at the Marshall house, and then went and passed an hour with Mr John Sargeant— He is a member of the House of Representatives of the United States elect, and engaged to go on with me, Saturday Morning, by the new Rail-road from Wilmington to Baltimore— W. B. Read came in, while I was there— I returned to the Marshall House and by nine O’Clock was in bed.
Day— In transitu— Et fugiunt fraeno non remorante dies.
